*[Bug 18851] could default argument for 'last' in substring() be changed?*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18851>

--- Comment #15 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Well, more testing *does* help and raises a further issue, I quickly had in
mind here, but then forgot about:
`as.integer(.)` in R  is much general than  `coerceVector(., INTSXP)` in R's C
API:

```
Int <- setClass("Int", contains="integer")
substring("substring", Int(2), Int(4))
## [1] "ubs"

Int2 <- setClass("Int2", representation= representation(i="integer"))
setMethod(as.integer, "Int2", \(x) x@i)

(st <- Int2(i = 2L))
substring("substring", st, Int(4)) # is problematic *after* patch
## whereas  "of course"
substring("substring", as.integer(st), Int(4)) # continues to work
```

R 4.5.1:
```
> substring("substring", st, Int(4))
[1] "ubs"
```

whereas in R-devel with the patch applied
```
> substring("substring", as.integer(st), Int(4)) # continues to work
[1] "ubs"
> substring("substring", st            , Int(4)) # fails:
Error in substring("substring", Int2(i = 2L), Int(4)) : 
  no method for coercing this S4 class to a vector
```
because C's  `coerceVector(.)` does *not* know about the R-level
`as.integer()` method.  

However, I'm completely surprised that this works with non-trivial S3 class:
```
s3int <- function(i) structure(list(i = i), class = "s3int")
substring("substring", s3int(2), 4)
```
Amazingly:
```
> substring("substring", s3int(2), 4)
[1] "ubs"
> 
```
and yes,  also `as.integer(s3int(2))` does nicely work.

To be really back compatible, it seems we need to use  R code such as

`.Internal(substr(text, as.integer(start), if(!is.null(stop))
as.integer(stop))`
using the subtle fact that `else NULL` is default for the `if()` function
.. and then, of course also, we can remove the part from the C code which tests
`start` to be integer ...

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18746>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------

--- Comment #5 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Comparing R objects/values is a very complex task and it is inevitable that the
documentation cannot cover all the details. It might be best to leave this
undocumented.

I agree we shouldn't be advertising that one can currently have an S4 object
without a class attribute, so that we can instead eventually get rid of that
option.

I think even asS4() should be regarded as a very low-level method that ideally
wouldn't be used by users or general packages. This is not the normal way to
create S4 objects.

I am not able to comment on the linked data.table code, I don't know enough
context, what the functions are meant to be doing. Of course it would be
simpler if data.table could use the duplication code provided by base R, but I
don't know the constraints. It might be best to ask such questions on R-devel
list (or maybe R-pkg-devel).

*[Bug 18723] more complete documentation of argument 'recursive' of 'c', 'unlist'*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18723>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #2 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I don't think the documentation should go to such details about objects that
most users wouldn't ever directly encounter - that would make the documentation
overly complicated.

The proposed patch is small, but I think one would have to write much more to
make the concepts around representing the code abstract syntax tree
understandable. In practice, one wouldn't encounter objects like expression(1,
2, "4"), but say expression(x^2 - 2*x + 1), and I think one wouldn't use
c(,recursive=TRUE) nor unlist() on them. But if explaining how these functions
work on them, the natural questions then would be how symbols are treated, how
language objects (the pairlist-based objects) are treated, etc. I think these
things are implementation details that might change in case with some
optimizations or if we changed the parser a bit. Also explaining that properly
would take a lot of space and effort.

I understand you came up with these questions when reading the implementation,
but in principle, if someone was implementing a tool working on an AST of R,
and wanted to be as defensive as possible to reduce the risk of breakage on R
updates, one could restrict primarily to the use of AST elements that is in
base R elsewhere, in this case primarily in the code of the byte-code compiler.
The compiler is itself implemented in R and the code is documented in quite a
bit of detail (the code and documentation are together in a single source
file).
